awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:    Production Optimization of Piezoelectric Fibers to Power Smart Garments
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will focus on the development of a piezoelectric energy harvesting fiber to autonomously power sensors and other low-power electronics in smart garments. This technology will allow the fabrication of garments with seamlessly integrated energy harvesting systems, as opposed to today's rigid electronics, to enable smart garments to move toward the same breathability, fit and comfort as normal clothing. The smart garments market is forecast to continue growing at nearly 20% per year over the next several years, reaching $2 billion by 2018. While there has been significant publicity around the development of smart garments for measuring various physiological conditions of athletes, the broader impact of this technology includes applications for monitoring soldiers, emergency responders and patients where the loss of sensor power (e.g. for body function monitoring or environmental sensing) could be dire. While this project will focus on one particular fiber chemistry, the expected learning that will result in terms of fiber processing and integration into fabric structures will also be applicable to other fiber technologies.

The intellectual merit of this project is associated with understanding the behavior of fiber-based piezoelectrics as they are processed into yarns and fabrics. Historically, ceramic and polymer piezoelectric materials are used in rigid or flexible film forms, which are not suitable for the development of wearable textile-based technologies. This effort focuses on a new class of piezoelectric polymer fiber, poly(gamma-benzyl-alpha,L-glutamate) (ePBLG), than can be produced in a single electrospinning process and without the need for physical or chemical post-processing to yield its piezo-activity. The three primary goals of the work will be: understanding the effect of polymer and process conditions on fiber dielectric properties, assessing and optimizing the mechanical and dielectric properties of ePBLG yarns, and evaluating the electrical output of a variety of orthogonal electrodes, as would be appropriate for woven fabric constructions. Through this work we will determine the effects on power output when transforming the ePBLG material into structures required for seamless incorporation into smart garments. With this knowledge, the piezoelectric power supply can be properly sized for the balance-of-system within a specific smart garment design.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The results of this work provides needed relationships in three key areas of piezoelectric materials: the effect of electrospinning conditions on piezo fiber properties, the effect of the fiber to yarn formation process on piezo and physical properties, and the effect of electrode configuration on energy harvesting of woven structures containing piezoelectric yarns.  These relationships are critical for the future integration of piezoelectric fibers and yarns into energy harvesting textiles, regardless of the fiber material chemistry.

These objectives were approached through six Tasks:

• Task 1. Preparation of PBLG fibers
• Task 2. Evaluation of PBLG fibers
• Task 3. Preparation of PBLG yarns
• Task 4. Mechanical and piezoelectric characterization of PBLG yarns
• Task 5. Analysis of orthogonal electrode structures with PBLG yarns
• Task 6. Commercial Assessment

Solutions of the three molecular weight PBLG materials were prepared in DCM and THF. The THF solutions were notably higher viscosity than equivalent DCM solutions and necessitated a reduction in solids to produce a spinnable solution. The High-MW material in THF was semi-gelled and a lower solids solution was not found that would yield good fiber generation. The two lower molecular weight materials were spun successfully in THF and all three from DCM.

X-ray diffraction of the PBLG fiber mat confirmed the expected structure as seen by the strong reflection at 2q ~7o, corresponding to the a-helix spacing of crystalline PBLG. THF solutions did provide notably finer fibers. However, within the error of the method, all PBLG molecular weights provided similar fiber sizes for a given spinning solvent. Electrical measurements for d33 piezoelectric coefficient determination were evaluated by both quasi-static and dynamic methods.

Yarn samples having a linear fiber density of 2300 denier (g/9000m) and 12 TPI (twists per inch) were produced to use for subsequent weaving experiments. This yarn is at the upper end of what would be required for heavy duty applications (first responder, military, etc.) and finer yarns were produced by simply reducing the amount of initial fiber mat material used for the yarn.

To normalize break strength, commonly termed Tenacity for yarns, the grams of force to break a yarn is divided by the yarn weight. For our studies, we have used yarn weight in Denier (g per 9000 m of yarn) to yield normalized Tenacity values in units of g/denier. Two variables in the production of yarn were studied: 1) yarn weight and 2) yarn twist rate in TPI. In comparing Tenacity for varying yarn weights with low TPI and high TPI, we did not see a significant effect from yarn weight. In fact, the slight differences in each set are likely due to varying twist rates. Within this set of replicates and twist rates, a trend of higher tenacity is observed for the higher twist rates.

We succeeded in weaving textile structures that includes orthogonal 316L stainless steel yarn. Electrical measurements confirmed that a signal of over 200mV could be measured from the orthogonal electrodes when stretching a 5-6 inch textile containing a single strand of PBLG yarn. To ensure the signal output was not an artifact of static buildup, an identical structure absent the PBLG yarn was woven and output measured. This structure showed no electrical signal on the orthogonal electrodes.

The results of the Phase I program have been critical in reaching three key technical milestones that have established the feasibility of using a piezoelectric yarn for sensing and energy harvesting in smart textiles:

1. Fabrication of a yarn that maintains piezoelectric activity of the original electrospun fibers was demonstrated

2. Fabrication of a yarn of suitable strength to allow its incorporation into woven structures was demonstrated

3. Fabrication of a textile with woven piezoelectric yarn demonstrated the capability of generating an electrical response that could be detect through integrated conductive electrode yarns

In addition, the manufacturing analysis has led to interactions with multiple companies capable of supplying both raw materials and equipment needed for scale up.

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2017
Modified by: Scott Gaboury
